thread.title: Carson holds low-key book signing at Barnes and Noble
thread.title_full: Carson holds low-key book signing at Barnes and Noble

title: Carson holds low-key book signing at Barnes and Noble
text:
Carson holds low-key book signing at Barnes and Noble UPDATED 10:36 PM CDT Oct 24, 2015 Show Transcript Hide Transcript 
While the Jefferson Jackson Dinner attracted large crowds and household names, such as pop singer Katy Perry and former President Bill Clinton, the new GOP front-runner was on the other side of town at the West Des Moines Barnes & Noble signing his book "A More Perfect Union." Other Stories 
Some 600 people snaked through the aisles to meet Ben Carson, who now leads in the Quinnipiac and Des Moines Register polls, at the low-key event. 
Ten-year-old Jenna Howe walked away with a signed copy of Carson's book. 
"He said, 'Hello, nice to meet you,'" she said. 
Her father, Jeffe Howe, said, "I asked her if she wanted to come, and she said she was very excited to see him and meet him. So she was the driving factor for us to stop today." 
Carson said he isn't going to get "overly excited" about the latest polls indicating he's overtaken billionaire businessman Donald Trump atop the field of Republican candidates. 
"I realize that the election is still 13 months away, but I'd rather be at the top than at the bottom of the polls," the former neurosurgeon laughed. 
"He's a humble man that we'd like to see as president," said supporter Bruce Roberts, who calls Carson a man of the people. "I think that's what the American people want right now is someone that is not in the political realm, where they'll actually do something positive for our country and make some real changes." 
Roberts' 1-year-old grandson, Josh, may have been wheeled away from the event with the most special memento â€“ the doctor's signature on his cast. 
"They're gonna be pretty impressed at day care," his grandfather said. 
"We'll definitely keep it after we cut it off," his mother, Lindsay Hernandez, said. Tags Ben Carson Quinnipiac Des Moines Register poll Barnes and Noble 
THE SECOND POLL THIS WEEK WITH CARSON OUT ON FRONT. KCCI'S KIM ST. ONGE SHOWS US HOW CARSON'S SOFT SELL IS WINNING SUPPORTERS IN IOWA. KIM: WHILE IT SEEMED LIKE A CONTEST OF WHO COULD BE THE LOUDEST OVER ON 5TH AVENUE -- CLINTON, PRESIDENT! KIM: ACROSS TOWN -- ? BEN CARSON SUPPORTERS RALLIED ON A LEVEL SEVERAL DECIBELS LOWER. 1, 2, 3. KIM: SOME 600 PEOPLE SNAKED THROUGH THE AISLES AT BARNES AND NOBLE IN WEST DES MOINES FOR A CHANCE TO MEET THE NEW REPUBLICAN FRONTRUNNER. JENNA: HE SAID, "HELLO, NICE TO MEET YOU." KIM: 10-YEAR-OLD JENNA HOWE WALKED AWAY WITH A SIGNED COPY OF CARSON'S BOOK. JEFF: I ASKED HER IF SHE WANTED TO COME. SHE WAS VERY EXCITED TO SEE HIM AND MEET HIM, SO SHE WAS THE ACTUAL DRIVING FACTOR FOR US TO STOP TODAY. KIM: CARSON SAYS HE ISN'T GOING TO GET OVERLY EXCITED ABOUT THE LATEST POLLS SHOWING HE'S LEADING THE PACK. DR. BEN CARSON: I REALIZE THAT THE ELECTION IS STILL, YOU KNOW, 13 MONTHS AWAY. BUT I'D RATHER BE ON THE TOP THAN AT THE BOTTOM OF THE POLLS. BRUCE: HE'S A HUMBLE MAN THAT WE'D LIKE TO SEE AS PRESIDENT. KIM: BRUCE ROBERTS CALLS CARSON A MAN OF THE PEOPLE. BRUCE: I THINK THAT'S WHAT THE AMERICAN PEOPLE WANT RIGHT NOW. SOMEONE THAT, IN THE POLITICAL REALM, WHERE THEY'LL ACTUALLY DO SOMETHING POSITIVE FOR OUR COUNTRY AND MAKE SOME REAL CHANGES. KIM: HIS ONE-YEAR-OLD GRANDSON, JOSH, MAY HAVE BEEN WHEELED AWAY FROM THE EVENT WITH THE MOST SPECIAL MOMENTO. THEY'RE GOING TO BE PRETTY IMPRESSED AT DAYCARE. KIM: THE DOCTOR'S SIGNATURE ON HIS CAST. LINDSAY: WE'LL DEFINITELY KEEP IT, AFTER WE CUT IT OFF.
